newsitem.title: GERMANY: German SPD demands fresh Bonn offer on tax reform.
newsitem.headline: German SPD demands fresh Bonn offer on tax reform.

text.p: Oskar Lafontaine, leader of Germany's opposition Social Democrats (SPD), on Thursday repeated the party's demand that Chancellor Helmut Kohl's coalition set out a new tax reform plan before talks on the stalled issue could resume.
Lafontaine said he was sceptical of an offer by Wolfgang Schaeuble, parliamentary leader of Kohl's Christian Democrats, to return to the bargaining table.
In an interview with Deutschlandradio Berlin, Lafontaine said before such talks could take place the government must set out a plan that would not wreak havoc with public finances.

Hamburg Mayor Henning Voscherau, another SPD budget expert, said Bonn's tax reform plan, which includes 30 billion marks ($16.4 billion) in tax cuts, lacked solid financing and would leave government coffers 45 billion marks short.
The SPD used its majority in the upper house of parliament to block the government's tax reform plan last month.
-- Terence Gallagher, Bonn newsroom, 49-228-26097150 ($ = 1.831 German Marks)
